text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of calendar text on the left, flanked by a continuous red-and-blue border on three sides; two circular roundel illustrations inset into the right margin; a large ornamental initial at top left; wide margins framing the content

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata book hand with frequent abbreviations, alternating red and blue majuscules with white vine-stem ornament

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for roundel backgrounds and frames; blue backgrounds in medallions and initials signal importance; red used in border framing and feast names; green accents on foliage; layered white highlights on drapery; alternating red and blue initials reinforce textual hierarchy

features: Vertical alignment of two circular medallions
Central placement of figures within each roundel

decorative_elements: Burnished gold bezants in roundel frames
Alternating colored initials with flourished penwork

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen outlines in brown ink with variable weight and confident contours
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal tonal modeling through light wash and selective white highlights, limited parallel hatching in drapery folds
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Flat spatial treatment with overlapping elements suggesting depth, hierarchical scaling absent, figures sized uniformly

reading_order: Top roundel then bottom roundel, read vertically

scene_relationships.subject: Harvesting grapes from a vine
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to wine production illustrated below

scene_relationships.subject: Treading or pressing grapes in a vat

visual_continuity: Burnished gold backgrounds in both scenes
Consistent palette of red, blue, and green
Thematic link of vine and vat imagery

content_theme.scene_description: In the upper right medallion, a peasant in a red tunic and hose bends forward to cut clusters of purple grapes from a stylized green vine, depositing them into a wicker basket at his feet; his simple leather shoes, close-fitting cap, and sturdy posture denote rural labor. In the lower medallion, a similarly dressed figure stands with legs apart within a shallow circular vat, holding a long wooden pole to turn and press the harvested grapes; his pinkish tunic edged in green and the gold-lined interior of the vat emphasize the importance of wine production. Both scenes are confined within burnished gold roundels set against flat ultramarine backgrounds, framed by square red borders with white-vine ornament. Figures overlap the roundel boundaries slightly, suggesting spatial extension, yet depth remains minimal. The red-and-blue rectilinear border unifies the two medallions, while the large ornate initial balances the page visually. These images serve as marginal seasonal indicators complementary to the Latin calendar entries.

secular: Peasant man harvesting grapes in red tunic and hose
Peasant man treading grapes in wooden vat with pole

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum, smooth, thin, ruled for calendar entries with visible pricking in gutter, consistent quaternion gatherings
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent pigment preservation with minimal red flaking, slight darkening of iron-gall ink, stable gold leaf with minor abrasion
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso beneath gold leaf in roundels
Visible ruling lines for text and border alignment

secondary_functions: Visual reminder of seasonal agricultural cycle

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This calendar page, likely from a mid–14th-century Book of Hours produced in a secular workshop in northern France, exemplifies the integration of devotional practice and the calendrical representation of agricultural labor. The precise Gothic textura quadrata script, alternating red and blue initials, and burnished gold backgrounds in the marginal roundels reflect a high level of technical achievement and a patronage context emphasizing luxury. The seasonal labors of harvesting and pressing grapes not only mark the month of September but also signal the importance of viticulture in medieval society. The ornamental initial with white-vine foliate patterns and the meticulous border framing demonstrate adherence to the Parisian illumination tradition, yet the naturalistic depiction of the vine and the peasant figures suggests an English Channel School influence. Material analysis reveals premium calfskin vellum and elaborate gesso work beneath gold leaf, indicating substantial expense and skilled craftsmanship. Iconographically, the inclusion of labor scenes in a devotional book reinforces the intertwining of sacred time and everyday life, offering the user both a mnemonic device for feast days and a reflection on God’s providence in the natural world. Comparatively, this leaf shares compositional strategies with the Psalter of Blanche of Castile, yet its dual-seasonal roundels and symmetrical layout represent an innovative approach to calendar illumination, balancing tradition with inventive marginal design.
